content.text: Welcome to the Albert Cuypmarkt! In this lesson, you'll learn how to order a famous Dutch treat: a fresh, warm stroopwafel. Let's start with how to greet the vendor.

data.tip: The 'g' sound in Dutch is a soft, throaty sound, similar to the 'ch' in the Scottish 'loch'.

content.title: Place Your Order
content.setting: You're at a busy stroopwafel stall in the Albert Cuyp market. The vendor smiles at you.

conversation_flow.title: Order one stroopwafel, please.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Goedemorgen! Wat mag het zijn voor jou?
conversation_flow.final_message: Natuurlijk! Eén verse, warme stroopwafel. Komt eraan!

content.text: Great! The vendor is making your stroopwafel. Now, let's learn how to ask for the price and say you're paying with cash.
The word 'alstublieft' is versatile. You use it for 'please' when ordering, and also when you hand something to someone, like money.

content.title: Confirm and Pay
content.setting: The vendor finishes making the stroopwafel and turns back to you, holding it out.

conversation_flow.title: Ask for the price.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Zo, hier is je stroopwafel. Dat is dan twee euro.

conversation_flow.title: Say that you will pay with cash.
Hand over the money and say 'please'.

content.text: Excellent! You've paid. Now let's learn how to properly thank the vendor and say goodbye before you enjoy your treat.
Use 'dank je wel' when talking to peers or in informal situations like a market. Use 'dank u wel' in more formal settings.

data.Dag: Bye (can be used for hello and goodbye)

content.title: Receive and Depart
content.setting: The vendor has taken your money and now hands you the warm stroopwafel.

conversation_flow.title: Take the stroopwafel and say 'Thank you'.
